title: Successful Radical Innovation: From ideas to market
abstractText:
The seminar series aim was to contribute to a deeper understanding of Radical Innovation (RI) in order to develop an interdisciplinary research agenda offering theoretical insight and practical relevance.

The series focused on six key core issues:

  • defining and measuring RI
  • understanding the RI process
  • the importance of relationships and networks in RI
  • barriers to RI exploitation
  • the role of Universities and other stakeholders in knowledge transfer
  • the unintended consequences of RI. Speakers included academics, offering insights from a range of disciplines and perspectives, and practitioners; presenting organisational experiences.

Participant engagement generated significant debate and suggests that outputs of the series will offer important insights in areas such as:

  • changing organisational practices to facilitate RI
  • improving RI commercialisation and exploitation
  • the value of wider stakeholders in successful RI development, particularly the role of Government and Universities in enabling knowledge generation and transfer, supporting network development and developing sectoral leadership
  • the need to understand the unintended consequences of RI, eg predicting potential failures through better forecasting/experimental techniques and improving feedback loops with designers
  • the social implications of RIs, both positive and negative.

The seminar series also facilitated strong network development and new research collaborations.
